results.title: Why are you crying, Antonio?
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Chamberlain, Mussolini and their aides attend a 1938 performance of Macbeth in Rome. This audience is itself made into the raw material of opera. The site of the negotiations between Chamberlain and Hitler, which resulted in the invasion of Czechoslovakia, is diagrammed, and Chamberlain and his aides are charged with lack of fantasy, a fatal flaw. Meanwhile, in September 1939 a Nazi officer’s happy love story is interrupted only to be resumed (we are told) in 1953, as he comes back from Soviet captivity. A film clip of two bodies in the midst of war devastation asks, "Why are you crying, Antonio? Are you afraid to die?" The theme of ‘a new beginning’ is the fantasy outcome here, as a ‘film’ in computer graphics shows a parade of French soldiers in 1918 celebrating the end of war in disbelief and hunger for freedom.

results.title: Why'd the beetle cross the road?
results.brief_description: In answer to the question which has puzzled sages throughout the centuries, this short whimsical film gives us a bug’s eye view of the meaning of life. It stars a determined beetle who slowly makes his way across an ocean-side bikepath, humming a medley of familiar tunes while he evades or surmounts a series of obstacles.

results.title: Whore
results.creator_credit: Ken Russell, Ronaldo Vasconcellos, Dan Ireland and Trimark Pictures
results.brief_description: Whore tells the story of one night in the life of a prostitute. Liz, (Theresa Russell) is a street wise hooker who has seen it all and done it all. In contrast to “Pretty Woman”, this film does not glamorise prostitution. This is a brash, vulgar depiction of the profession. Although exploitative and titillating in itself, it does raise issues often overlooked in more romantic interpretations, including legalisation, safe sex, drug abuse and the relationship between sex and power.

results.title: Whole School Planning
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Institute of Educational Administration
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Case studies in effective schooling”.
Case studies in effective schooling presents first hand accounts of how individual schools have improved their effectiveness. The first episode, “Whole school planning” looks at planning as a manageable series of arrangements designed to involve all interested parties and to make the best use of limited resources. Deer Park Secondary College features in this case study.

results.title: Whole lotta shaking: R.E.S.P.E.C.T.
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Hugh Thompson, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
Whole lotta shakin examines the grass roots beginnings of rock and roll. In New Orleans, Afro-american performers like Little Richard were unleashing a new type of music which echoed through the Mississippi Delta into Sam Phillips’ Studio in Memphis. What was predominantly Afro-american music became “legitimised” commercially when singers like Elvis Presley emulated this energetic form of music. “R.E.S.P.E.C.T”: Motown and Stax records paved the way for legendary Afro-american singers to become successful in their own right. Aretha Franklin was the Queen of Soul, but artists like Ray Charles, Martha Reeves, Otis Redding and the Supremes also made their mark as rock and roll legends.

results.title: Whoever says the truth shall die : A film about Pier Paolo Pasolini
results.creator_credit: Philo Bregstein, Frank Diamond, Harry Prins and VPRO
results.brief_description: Whoever Says the Truth Shall Die is a naked-truth documentary on the life and work of Italian filmmaker Pier Paolo Pasolini. Using still pictures, excerpts and extensive interviews, director Philo Bregstein charts Pasolini’s matriculation into one of the most controversial cinematic figures in the world. The film includes interviews with Pasolini’s long term collaborator, the actress Laura Betti, author Alberto Moravia, director Bernardo Bertolucci and others.

results.title: Who will teach your child?
results.creator_credit: Stanley Jackson, Gudrun Parker and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: An analysis of the teacher’s vital role in a child’s development. Three important questions are raised; how can we attract people of superior ability to the teaching profession; how should these people be trained; once trained, how can they be persuaded to stay in the profession thus giving up more lucrative careers. Various classroom situations are used to emphasize the important part played by the teacher in moulding the development of the child. The film presents a challenge to all concerned - prospective teacher, parent, the community as a whole - for the teaching profession to receive true recognition and for children to find satisfaction in their search for knowledge.
